awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Development and optimization of a novel lightweight and impact-resistant composite
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is a unique continuous-fiber composite that is lightweight and offers enhanced impact resistance and energy absorbance compared to commercially available carbon fiber composites. The demand for advanced composite materials is expected to steadily increase both in the United States and worldwide due to rapid growth in aerospace and automotive applications, as well as defense and clean energy applications. Though valued for their high strength-to-weight and lightweight properties, traditional and commonly-utilized fiber-reinforced composites composed of carbon fiber or fiberglass tend to exhibit brittle properties and low impact tolerance. Lack of damage tolerance leads to various forms of localized and nonlocalized material failure, compromising the material's structural integrity and incurring replacement costs and scrap waste. Developing composite materials that can withstand impact scenarios and possess damage tolerance is necessary to enable more widespread adoption of these materials across a variety of applications.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will explore material development and processing methodologies to progress and optimize the performance of the proposed novel composite material. The project will evaluate the feasibility of formulations composed of different iterations of this material technology while evaluating pre- and post-processing techniques for performance and scalability. Additional refinement strategies such as enhancing the fiber-matrix bond for enhanced anti-crack propagation and energy distribution will also be explored. This will be coupled with testing methodologies demonstrating various material property classifications as well as application-specific, proof-of-concept testing to demonstrate performance effectiveness. The goal is to approach the isotropic properties and impact resistance of high-performance metal alloys while retaining the lightweight, high strength-to-weight performance of carbon fiber composites.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In response to these market shortcomings, Parisi Technologies, LLC has developed AVAX™, a novel and patented composite material with competitive weight savings, enhanced impact resistance of over 60% compared with highly technical composites, such as aerospace-grade carbon fiber-epoxy composites, but at almost identical weight savings advantages. Unlike conventional composites, AVAX™ consists is a toughened solution with superior fiber-matrix adhesion and energy distribution throughout the system when impacted. As current traditional composites on the market lack impact resistance due to fibers having to carry most of the applied stress loads, making them brittle and easily damaged with common failure modes such as compressive failure, buckling, ply-splitting, fiber-matrix debonding, and delamination, as well as a “relaxation phenomenon” that makes internal damage difficult to detect. Therefore, crack propagation can occur from low-impact events such as daily wear and tear and high-impact scenarios in which immediate rupture or even catastrophic failure can occur. AVAX™ enhanced damage resistance both mitigates crack propagation and retains residual strength.

 AVAX™ can be easily adapted to seamlessly replace traditional composite materials leading to longer product lifecycles and time repairing or replacing composite structures, as well as a sustainable reduction in scrap costs. Being an industry disruptor, further weight savings can be achieved by substituting AVAX™ in applications that are currently reserved for tougher metallic materials such as aluminum and steel, which brittle carbon fiber composites have been unable to replace. For example, substituting just 5% of aluminum with AVAX™ in a 737 MAX 8 aircraft could save 3.5 million gallons of fuel that equivalates to costs savings of 7 USD million over 25 years.

 AVAX™ is a platform technology offering competitive weight savings, enhanced impact resistance, and increased robustness products currently on the market, especially in applications such as aerospace, defense, automotive, space, etc., where superior performance, weight savings, and safety are pivotal. Parisi will commercialize AVAX™ in critical industry markets (transportation, space, defense) with similar end-user pain points where strength performance and weight savings are key.

 


Last Modified: 03/05/2022
Modified by: Emily Parisi
